moves.1. e4: I already had one game played against woody17, a long game that ended in a tough loss. But the first game was so competitive, even though I ended up on the wrong side of the ledger, that we decided to play again. This game shows that if you play mistake-free, you can get a result even against someone ranked 200 points higher...
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5: When I'm not doing unusual openings as White, I'm partial to the Ruy Lopez.
moves.3... Nd4 4. Nxd4 exd4: The exchange means Black will have to defend his advanced Pawn at d5. It could easily fall, but if it doesn't, it will cramp White's Queen-side development.
moves.5. O-O Bc5 6. d3: Solidifying the center...for both players. But I felt I had to open the diagonal for my Queen Bishop, and it also blocks a future advance of Black's d-pawn.
moves.8. Bb3 d6 9. a3: Creates a retreat for the Bishop, if necessary. A future advance of the b-pawn to freeze Black's Queen-side ambitions is also set up.
moves.9... Nf6 10. Bg5 O-O: Both players just need to complete their Queen-side development, and the middle-game can begin.
moves.11. Nd2 h6 12. Bh4 g5: Black weakens his King's defenses, but eliminates the pin on his Knight.
moves.13. Bg3 Bg4 14. f3 Bh5 15. Qe2: White's development is now complete. Neither side has done much, although Black has a slight spatial advantage.
moves.15... Re8 16. Kh1 Bg6: Black is focusing on White's e-pawn, but it's well guarded. Both players need to move their pieces to the King-side if they wish to attack.
moves.17. Rae1 Nh5 18. Ba2: White intends Nb3, trying to remove Black's dark-squared Bishop.
moves.19. Qd1 Nxg3+ 20. hxg3: Black wins the minor exchange and weakens the defenses of White's King. However, getting pieces over to the h-file to launch an attack will not be easy, given the congestion on that side of the board.
moves.20... c6 21. b4: Black's Queen-side prospects are cut off.
moves.21... c5 22. Nb1 Qc7: Black is positioning the Queen for a diagonal attack on White's King-side.
moves.23... gxf4 24. gxf4: The exchange has opened up an avenue for Black's Queen to attack, but also created more flight squares for White's King and undoubled the Pawns.
moves.24... Qe7 25. Bd5: Centralizing the Bishop, though with no real threats. It does make Black have to move his Queen Rook out of the line of fire.
moves.26... Qh4+: As expected. But Black can't get more than his Queen into the attack, rendering it less effective.
moves.29. Nd2: A tactical interlude. Black is given the opportunity to exchange Queens.
moves.29... Qxf1+ 30. Rxf1: Black removes one of White's Rooks.
moves.30... Bxd1 31. Bxf7+: White wins back the Pawn. After all the tactics are played out, material will be even.
moves.31... Kg7 32. Bxe8: Black will end up ahead a minor exchange, but in the endgame, that's a difficult advantage to exploit.
moves.32... Rxe8 33. Rxd1 Bd8: With Black having a dark-squared Bishop, White can minimize the effectiveness of the piece by placing his own pieces on white squares.
moves.34. Rf1 Rf8 35. Rxf8 Kxf8: The Rooks come off, and the maneuvering begins. A long endgame will ensue.
moves.36. Nb1 a5 37. bxa5 Bxa5: A pair of Pawns go. White has only one Pawn left on a black square.
moves.38. Kf2 Kf7 39. Kf3 Kf6: The Kings move towards the battleground.
moves.40. Kf4 Bc7 41. Kg4 Kg6: If White can exchange off his a-pawn, he can form an impenetrable barrier on the white squares.
moves.42. Kf3 Kg5 43. Nd2 Ba5 44. Nb1 b4: This gives White his opportunity. Now if neither side blunders, a draw will result.
moves.45. axb4 Bxb4: Notice that since every single White piece is on a white square, Black's bishop is essentially useless as an attacking piece.
White clearly is content with a draw. Black has no way to force a win, although he could try exchanging his Bishop for White's Knight and attempting to win in the King and Pawn endgame.
moves.50... Bg3 51. Kf3 h4 52. Nd2 Bf4 53. Nf1: This time, Black accepts. A well-played game by both sides, and a deserved result.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C61), Bird's defence, Paulsen variation
